docs.title: A Practical Guide to Large Language Models (LLMs) — Strengths & Best Uses
docs.text: This post compares major LLM families (OpenAI GPT, Anthropic Claude, Google Gemini/PaLM, Meta Llama, Mistral, Falcon/MPT, and other alternatives), explains their strengths and weaknesses, and recommends which to choose for chat assistants, code, RAG, on-device inference, and cost-sensitive workflows.

docs.title: Why this guide
docs.text:
• Inputs: You need to pick an LLM for a concrete task (chatbot, summarization, code assistant, RAG, or self-hosting).
  • Outputs: Short list of recommended models, strengths/weaknesses, example prompts, and a quick decision checklist.

docs.title: Strengths
docs.text:
• Best-in-class instruction following, reasoning, and code generation.
  • Rich SDKs, plugins, and production-ready tooling.

docs.title: Weaknesses
docs.text:
• Higher cost and vendor lock-in.
  • Data residency and privacy concerns for sensitive data.

docs.title: Best uses
docs.text:
• Production chat assistants that need tool use and high reliability.
  • High-quality summarization, content generation, and RAG generation.
  • Code completion, refactoring, and developer tooling.

docs.title: Example prompt
docs.text:
"Summarize the following text in 5 bullets focusing on action items and risks:"

The product launch was delayed three weeks due to supplier shortages. The engineering team recommends increasing vendor redundancy and adding a safety stock. Marketing timelines will shift and customer communications must be prepared. The finance team should review budget for expedited shipping options.

docs.title: Strengths
docs.text: • Safety-by-design and robust instruction following in long dialogues.

docs.title: Weaknesses
docs.text: • Responses can be conservative; smaller community ecosystem than OpenAI.

docs.title: Best uses
docs.text: • Customer support assistants and internal knowledge-base chatbots where safety is essential.

docs.title: Example prompt
docs.text: "You are a helpful, cautious assistant. If you are unsure, say what data you'd need to be certain."

docs.title: Strengths
docs.text: • Strong multimodal capabilities and integration with Google Cloud services.

docs.title: Weaknesses
docs.text: • Ecosystem lock-in and variable pricing models.

docs.title: Best uses
docs.text: • Multimodal applications (image+text) and enterprises already using GCP.

docs.title: Example prompt
docs.text: "Analyze the attached image and list three business insights with supporting evidence from the image."

docs.title: Strengths
docs.text: • Open weights, suitable for fine-tuning and on-prem self-hosting.

docs.title: Weaknesses
docs.text: • May lag behind proprietary top-performers on some benchmarks.

docs.title: Best uses
docs.text: • Self-hosted assistants, custom fine-tuning on proprietary data, and privacy-sensitive deployments.

docs.title: Example prompt
docs.text: "You are a company-specific assistant. Given this product manual, answer the user's question and cite sections used."

docs.title: Strengths
docs.text: • Efficient open-source models with strong performance for their size.

docs.title: Weaknesses
docs.text: • Ecosystem and tooling are newer and still maturing.

docs.title: Best uses
docs.text: • Cost-effective inference and on-prem quantized deployments.

docs.title: Example prompt
docs.text: "Generate a 3-paragraph overview of this research paper and list two follow-up experiments."

docs.title: Strengths
docs.text: • Flexible open models for experimentation and domain-specific fine-tuning.

docs.title: Weaknesses
docs.text: • Mixed benchmark results; production readiness may need extra engineering.

docs.title: Best uses
docs.text: • Research, domain fine-tuning, and custom workloads where licensing is favorable.

docs.title: Example prompt
docs.text: "Fine-tune this model to perform product categorization; outline a minimal dataset and training plan."

docs.title: Cohere, Aleph Alpha, and other providers
Strengths
docs.text: • Provider alternatives with good embeddings, multilingual support, and classification features.

docs.title: Best uses
docs.text: • Embeddings, multilingual classification, and specialized provider integrations.

docs.title: Example prompt
docs.text: "Return embeddings for these three documents and compute cosine similarities."

docs.title: Small comparison table
docs.text:
Model / Provider Strengths Best uses Latency Cost Fine-tuning Self-hostable Notes OpenAI GPT-4 Top accuracy, tooling, plugins Chat, code, RAG gen Medium High Limited (OpenAI fine-tune options) No (API) Excellent for production when budget allows Anthropic Claude Safety, long-dialog handling Support bots, safe assistants Medium Medium-High Vendor fine-tuning No (API) Strong safety posture Google Gemini/PaLM Multimodal, GCP integration Multimodal apps, enterprise Medium High API-based fine-tuning No (API) Great for image+text tasks Meta Llama 2/3 Open weights, self-hosting Fine-tuning, on-prem assistants Variable Low (self-host infra cost) Yes (community tools) Yes Good balance for privacy-focused apps Mistral Efficient, strong open performance Cost-effective inference Low-Medium Low Yes Yes Fast-moving open-source option Falcon / MPT Research & domain fine-tuning Experimentation, edge cases Variable Low Yes Yes Useful for custom workloads Cohere / Aleph Alpha Embeddings & multilingual Embeddings, classification Low-Medium Medium Yes No/limited Provider alternatives with unique strengths

Notes: "Latency" and "Cost" are generalizations — actual values depend heavily on hosting, model size, and usage pattern.

docs.title: Choosing by task (concise)
docs.text:
• Chat & reasoning: GPT-4 or Claude 3; self-hosted option — Llama 3 with RAG.
  • Code assistants: GPT-4 (best), or fine-tuned Llama/Mistral for on-prem.
  • RAG & long-docs: Use models with long-context support or combine embeddings + RAG with a strong generator (GPT, Claude).
  • Cost-sensitive bulk generation: GPT-3.5 or quantized Llama/Mistral/Falcon.
  • Multimodal: Gemini or OpenAI multimodal variants.
  • On-device/privacy: Quantized Llama, Mistral, Falcon with llama.cpp/ggml or vLLM.

docs.title: Quick decision checklist
docs.text:
1. Data sensitivity: must data stay on-prem? If yes → self-host (Llama/Mistral/Falcon).
  2. Budget per request: high → GPT-4; low → GPT-3.5 or quantized open models.
  3. Latency requirements: low-latency → smaller/quantized models near users.
  4. Integration needs: plugins/tools → OpenAI has richest ecosystem.
  5. Multimodal requirements: Gemini or OpenAI multimodal models.
  6. Need to fine-tune: prefer open weights (Llama family, Mistral) or providers with fine-tuning APIs.

docs.title: Practical prompts (examples)
docs.text:
• Summarization: "Summarize the following text in 5 bullets focusing on action items and risks:"
The product launch was delayed three weeks due to supplier shortages. The engineering team recommends increasing vendor redundancy and adding a safety stock. Marketing timelines will shift and customer communications must be prepared. The finance team should review budget for expedited shipping options.

  • Classification (few-shot): "Label the sentiment of these examples (POS/NEG/NEUTRAL). Return JSON array of labels."

    Example (few-shot input):

    Example 1: "I love the new update — the UI is so much cleaner and faster!"
Example 2: "The product crashed three times today. Very disappointing experience."
Example 3: "The feature works as expected; nothing surprising either way."

    Prompt instruction: "Label the sentiment of the examples above as POS, NEG, or NEUTRAL and return a JSON array of labels in the original order."

    Expected output (example):

    ["POS", "NEG", "NEUTRAL"]

  • RAG assistant: "Given the retrieved documents below and the user question, provide a concise answer and cite document IDs used."

    Example (retrieved docs + question):

    [DOC_1] Title: Supplier report
Content: "Supplier A reported delays in shipments for component X due to raw material shortages."

[DOC_2] Title: Engineering notes
Content: "Team recommends increasing vendor redundancy and maintaining a two-week safety stock."

User question: "Why was the product launch delayed and what should we do next?"

    Prompt instruction: "Answer concisely using the retrieved documents. Cite the document IDs (e.g., DOC_1, DOC_2) used for each statement."

    Example expected answer:

    The launch was delayed due to supplier shortages for component X (DOC_1). Recommended next steps: increase vendor redundancy and maintain a two-week safety stock to mitigate future delays (DOC_2).

  • Code explanation: "Explain the following Python function in simple terms and suggest two tests for edge cases:"

def is_prime(n):
    """Return True if n is a prime number, otherwise False."""
    if n <= 1:
        return False
    i = 2
    while i * i <= n:
        if n % i == 0:
            return False
        i += 1
    return True

docs.title: Operational checklist (engineering)
docs.text:
• Start with a small POC to measure latency, cost, and hallucination rates.
  • For self-hosting, test quantized inference on your target hardware before committing to a model.
  • Add monitoring for hallucination, latency, and user satisfaction.

docs.title: Caveats
docs.text:
• Hallucination: All LLMs can hallucinate — use RAG/verification for critical outputs.
  • Safety: Add guardrails and human review for high-risk outputs.
  • Licensing: Check open-model licenses before commercial use.
